abstract.p: Venus Williams defeats Patty Schnyder to advance to semifinals of Pilot Pen tennis tournament; other Pilot Pen scores noted (S)

block.p: Venus Williams played only a bit better yesterday than she did in winning her opening match at the Pilot Pen tournament in New Haven. Still, it was good enough for her to beat Patty Schnyder, 6-4, 6-2, and advance to today's semifinals.
After winning her 17th consecutive match, Williams, the defending champion, conceded that she sometimes had trouble lifting her game against lesser opponents.

Venus Williams played only a bit better yesterday than she did in winning her opening match at the Pilot Pen tournament in New Haven. Still, it was good enough for her to beat Patty Schnyder, 6-4, 6-2, and advance to today's semifinals.
After winning her 17th consecutive match, Williams, the defending champion, conceded that she sometimes had trouble lifting her game against lesser opponents.
If I'm playing a top 10 player, for sure I'm going to play better, said the 20-year-old Williams, who has won three tournaments in a row starting with Wimbledon in July.
Williams, who will meet fifth-seeded Amanda Coetzer in the semifinals, certainly dropped the level of her play against the 21-year-old Schnyder, a former top 10 player now ranked 28th.
After taking a 2-0 lead, Williams lost her service three times in a row to enable Schnyder to take a 4-3 lead. By then Williams had committed 20 unforced errors and had four double faults.
Williams managed to run off the last three games to take the set. In the second set, she committed only seven unforced errors.
Williams, whose three defeats this year -- all on clay -- include one to Coetzer, said she was not concerned during the opening set.
''I think what happens is that I get a little too relaxed and a little too confident,'' Williams said. ''Even when I get behind, I feel like I'm going to win the match.''
